items.title: What you need to know about new CSS in 2022
items.content:
Frontend Focus

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹542 â€” May 18, 2022 | Read on the web

The State of CSS in 2022 â€” An introduction and overview of the CSS features and browser changes on slate for the rest of the year. Thereâ€™s a lot to look through here, including :has(), Viewport unit variants, subgrid, color-mix(), and much more. Itâ€™s a solid high level look at what you need to know about writing CSS in 2022 and beyond, with examples/resources to boot. Thereâ€™s also an accompanying video versionÂ here.

Adam Argyle

Web Applications 101 â€” A single article that touches on almost everything involved in building a modern Web site from the simplest of HTML pages through to server-side rendering (SSR) and static-site generation (SSG). Not a tutorial but gives you the broader, architecturalÂ picture.

Robin Wieruch

How to Create Dynamic Forms Using FormArray in Angular â€” Have you ever booked movie tickets online? If yes, then you have used a dynamic form. In this article, youâ€™ll learn to create a dynamic form in Angular and also hear a high-level explanation of other useful classes of Angular reactiveÂ forms.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

New WebKit Features in Safari 15.5 â€” Safari 15.5 is here, with support for the inert attribute, the worker-src Content Security Policy directive, APIs for implementing new viewport units in WKWebView, and manyÂ fixes.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Privacy is an essential part of the web. Now, the W3C TAG Privacy Principles Task Force has released a first public working draft of the Privacy Principles.

  • The Chrome team have decided to postpone the restriction on SharedArrayBuffer on desktop to Chrome 106 â€” it's to secure more time to introduce ways to relax the requirement to enable cross-origin isolation.

  • CSS Day is back in person next month. There's still a few tickets left if you fancy a trip to Amsterdam.

  • Dev browser Polypane just hit version nine, adding a screenshot editor, structured data support and new debug tools.

  • For the first time in a very long time, WordPress' market share is shrinking.

  • So, what happens to a TLD when a country stops existing?

  • This site highlights examples of low-carbon web design and development You can submit a site for inclusion too if you'd like.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

:where() :is() :has()? New CSS Selectors That Make Your Life Easier â€” An approachable look at these three new CSS selectors, how to use them, and the current levels of browser support forÂ each.

Kilian Valkhof (Polypane)

Rethinking Server-Timing as a Critical Monitoring Tool â€” Server-Timing is uniquely powerful as the only HTTP response header that supports setting free-form values for a specific resource and making them accessible via a browser API separate from the Request/Response referencesÂ themselves.

Sean Roberts

Level-Up Your Cypress Testing Knowledge for Free â€” Learn from top industry experts with over 25 lessons on how to get started withÂ Cypress.

Cypress.io sponsor

Syntax Highlighting (and More) with Prism on a Static Site â€” This post will show you how to implement syntax highlighting on a Next.js blog with the popular Prism.jsÂ library.

Adam Rackis

Theoretical Foundations for Server-Side Rendering and Static-Rendering â€” A research paper and proposal regarding rendering. It ultimately concludes that the distinction between pre-rendering (static) and SSR is somewhat blurry and proposes an API implementation wherein the framework chooses whether to serve up an existing pre-render or a server-rendered page without the developer needing to specify inÂ advance.

Eric Burel

How Modern Frameworks Perform on the New 'Interaction to Next Paint' (INP)Â Metric
Leena Sohoni, Addy Osmani, Keen Yee Liau

Quick Tip: You Might Not Need calc()
Michelle Barker

Jobs

Product Designer at Fleet (100% Remote) â€” We're building a better way to manage employee laptops and servers. We're looking for someone with design and frontend experience to join the team and help iterate our web and desktopÂ apps.
Fleet

AI & Software Engineers â€” Sticker Mule is the Internet's most "kick ass" brand. Our software team operates from 17 countries, and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.
Sticker mule

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Reagraph: WebGL Graph Visualizations for React â€” A high-performance network graph visualization library that uses WebGL under the hood for both 2D and 3D rendering options. Hereâ€™s a basic sandbox example you can playÂ with.

REAVIZ

Tweetic: Convert Tweets to Static HTML â€” Useful to preserve the look of a tweet longterm or possibly in HTML email. Also gives you the option to use plain CSS or Tailwind for theÂ styling.

Zernonia

DFlex: A Drag-and-Drop Library for All JS Frameworks â€” This is a vanilla JavaScript solution with a focus on good performance and easy implementation. Try some demos here.

DFlex

Find & Fix Your Accessibility Bugs. Free axe DevTools ChromeÂ Extension

Deque sponsor

Parvus: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies â€” I love how it says not to use overlays on Web pages but if you have to, use this! Thereâ€™s a CodePenÂ example.

Benjamin de Oostfrees

Shrink.media: An Online Tool to Reduce the Size of Images â€” There are certainly lots of similar tools, but this one has a nice UI where you can visually compare the images and use sliders to reduce the quality and physicalÂ size.

Shrink.media

Horizon UI: A Beautiful Open Source Admin Template for Chakra UI and React â€” Includes 70+ dark/light components covering a whole slew of UI possibilities. View a live previewÂ here.

Horizon UI

How To Build a Modal Dialog as a Web Component â€” â€œWrite once and run everywhere, so to speak, or at least that was my lofty aspiration. Good news. It is indeed possible to build a modal with rich interaction that only requires authoring HTML toÂ use.â€

Nathan Smith

Porting Zelda Classic to the Web â€” A fascinating write up of an amazing piece of work.. and thereâ€™s not a single line of JavaScript. Itâ€™s pretty amazing what the browser, WebAssembly, and compiler toolchains can do now and this shows it all off pretty well. If you prefer playing to reading, though, the end result isÂ here.

Connor Clark

Figma for Developers â€” Join Steve Kinney to learn how to confidently use Figma for creating user interface prototypes. Youâ€™ll also learn how to create reusable styles, typography, and components to create prototypes to show colleagues or customers before you build an entireÂ application.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Babylon.js 5.0: A Powerful 3D Web Rendering Engine â€” Babylon is a powerful framework you can use as the basis for games, visualizations, and other 3D and AR experiences running both natively and on the Web. As usual, they have a release video showing it off too or hit the playground to get playing with a basic example inÂ seconds.

  • @wayback_exe is a fantastic Twitter account I've been enjoying lately. It posts screenshots of (mostly) ancient Web pages each day.

'Please, Stop Disabling Zoom' â€” OK, sometimes there might be a good reason, but 9 times out of 10, youâ€™re probably going to be causing someone some accessibility problems on mobile, so donâ€™t just do it withoutÂ consideration.

The key, says this author, is to make the absolute minimum necessary the defaultÂ option.

Nicat Manafov

20minJS podcast

â–¶Â Â Serverless for Frontend Engineers with Swizec Teller â€” Swizec does courses in using React alongside serverless technologies and speaks with Jeremy and Rebecca here about approaching serverless as a frontend engineer, JavaScript, and troublesomeÂ tutorials.

Enter this â€˜minimal CSS framework switcherâ€™ where you get to preview lots of minimal CSS frameworks on a singleÂ page.

Liam Doherty

Useful Tools for Creating AVIF Images â€” AVIF (AV1 Image File Format) is a modern image file format which offer space and efficiency benefits over legacy alternatives. Its support is good in Firefox and Chrome but Safari has yet to get onÂ board.

Sunkanmi Fafowora

Project Management for Today's (and Tomorrow's) SoftwareÂ Teams

You Donâ€™t Need a UI Framework â€” Youâ€™ve got an app or a site to build so you reach for Bootstrap or Material UI and.. well, maybe you shouldnâ€™t, says Josh, who argues theyâ€™re not needed for most projects and makes his caseÂ here.

Josh Comeau

ğŸ‚ Â Celebrating Firefox 100: How Mozilla Got There â€” Just a month behind Chrome 100 comes Firefox 100, and how far Firefox has come since its birth as Phoenix, a lightweight rethinking of the former Netscape browser suite. Firefox 100 is broadly not a developer oriented release but there are release notes nonetheless.

Mozilla

Build a More Accessible Web App with axe DevTools â€” Start accessibility testing in your browser in just minutes. Avoid wasted time with inaccurate results. Easily fix issues with in-product guidance. Install the free axe DevTools Chrome extension and start building a more accessible appÂ today.

Deque sponsor

Flexibly Centering an Element with Side-Aligned Content â€” I'm old enough to remember when folks like Eric had to come up with complicated solutions for Web layout issues, so itâ€™s fantastic things have progressed that such solutions are now simple, yet still clever enough to involve CSS properties I've not used before such as max-inline-size here.

Eric Meyer

Microsoft Edge Overtakes Safari as 2nd Most Popular Desktop Browser â€” So now the #1 and #2 browser are, essentially, both Chromium under the hood for a total of 76.7% share between them. Safari is still huge in the mobile space, however, due to Appleâ€™s rules around browser engines (or lack thereof) on iOSÂ devices.

  • The CSS Zen Garden project has turned 19 years old.

  • Dave Rupert considers the complexity of server-side versus client-side analytics and concludes "If your goal is not to grow your siteâ€¦ maybe ignorance is bliss."
